projectDesc.p: This version of the Folger Digital Texts uses TEI Simple to encode the Shakespeare texts edited by Barbara Mowat and Paul Werstine. The major goal of recasting the texts in this manner is to make them interoperable with a large corpus of early modern texts derived from the EEBO-TCP transcriptions and encoded in TEI Simple with linguistic annotation.

For a full description of the encoding practices of the Folger Digital Texts consult their encodingDesc section. This version is completely faithful to the readings, orthogrgraphy, and punctuation of the source text. It uses a different XML encoding scheme, with occasional losses in expressiveness. The major differences are:
Number div are replaced by unnumbered divs
Lines of verse are marked in l, tags, lines of prose in ab
All xml:ids are corpuswide identifiers
Information from the participant description element particDesc in the teiHeader has been moved into a castList element in the front element
Each spoken word in the text has been linguistically annotated with a lemma and POS tag

refsDecl.p: Words, spaces, and punctuation characters are numbered sequentially, incremented by 10.

Most other elements begin with an element-specific prefix, followed by a reference to the Folger Through Line Number, a sequential numbering of the numbered lines in the text. If an element is inline with play text, it has the same line number as the line where it begins. If it begins on a line following play text, a decimal number is appended and incremented as necessary. If it falls between a speech prefix and the play text, a ".0" is appended to the value of the following line number.

div.head: Scene 1
div.stage: Dead March. Enter the funeral of King Henry the Fifth, attended on by the Duke of Bedford, Regent of France; the Duke of Gloucester, Protector; the Duke of Exeter; the Earl of Warwick; the Bishop of Winchester; and the Duke of Somerset, with Heralds and Attendants.

sp.speaker: BEDFORD
sp.l: Hung be the heavens with black, yield day to night!
Comets, importing change of times and states,
Brandish your crystal tresses in the sky,
And with them scourge the bad revolting stars
That have consented unto Henry’s death:
King Henry the Fifth, too famous to live long.
England ne’er lost a king of so much worth.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.l: England ne’er had a king until his time.
Virtue he had, deserving to command;
His brandished sword did blind men with his beams;
His arms spread wider than a dragon’s wings;
His sparkling eyes, replete with wrathful fire,
More dazzled and drove back his enemies
Than midday sun fierce bent against their faces.
What should I say? His deeds exceed all speech.
He ne’er lift up his hand but conquerèd.

sp.speaker: EXETER
sp.l: We mourn in black; why mourn we not in blood?
Henry is dead and never shall revive.
Upon a wooden coffin we attend,
And Death’s dishonorable victory
We with our stately presence glorify,
Like captives bound to a triumphant car.
What? Shall we curse the planets of mishap
That plotted thus our glory’s overthrow?
Or shall we think the subtle-witted French
Conjurers and sorcerers, that, afraid of him,
By magic verses have contrived his end?

sp.speaker: WINCHESTER
sp.l: He was a king blest of the King of kings;
Unto the French the dreadful Judgment Day
So dreadful will not be as was his sight.
The battles of the Lord of Hosts he fought;
The Church’s prayers made him so prosperous.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.l: The Church? Where is it? Had not churchmen prayed,
His thread of life had not so soon decayed.
None do you like but an effeminate prince
Whom like a schoolboy you may overawe.

sp.speaker: WINCHESTER
sp.l: Gloucester, whate’er we like, thou art Protector
And lookest to command the Prince and realm.
Thy wife is proud; she holdeth thee in awe
More than God or religious churchmen may.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.l: Name not religion, for thou lov’st the flesh,
And ne’er throughout the year to church thou go’st,
Except it be to pray against thy foes.

sp.speaker: BEDFORD
sp.l: Cease, cease these jars, and rest your minds in peace!
Let’s to the altar.— Heralds, wait on us.—
Instead of gold, we’ll offer up our arms,
Since arms avail not, now that Henry’s dead.
Posterity, await for wretched years
When at their mothers’ moistened eyes babes shall suck,
Our isle be made a nourish of salt tears,
And none but women left to wail the dead.
Henry the Fifth, thy ghost I invocate:
Prosper this realm, keep it from civil broils,
Combat with adverse planets in the heavens.
A far more glorious star thy soul will make
Than Julius Caesar or bright—

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: My honorable lords, health to you all.
Sad tidings bring I to you out of France,
Of loss, of slaughter, and discomfiture:
Guyen, Champaigne, Rheims, Roan, Orleance,
Paris, Gisors, Poitiers, are all quite lost.

sp.speaker: BEDFORD
sp.l: What say’st thou, man, before dead Henry’s corse?
Speak softly, or the loss of those great towns
Will make him burst his lead and rise from death.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.l: Is Paris lost? Is Roan yielded up?
If Henry were recalled to life again,
These news would cause him once more yield the ghost.

sp.speaker: EXETER
sp.l: How were they lost? What treachery was used?

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: No treachery, but want of men and money.
Amongst the soldiers, this is mutterèd:
That here you maintain several factions
And, whilst a field should be dispatched and fought,
You are disputing of your generals.
One would have ling’ring wars with little cost;
Another would fly swift, but wanteth wings;
A third thinks, without expense at all,
By guileful fair words peace may be obtained.
Awake, awake, English nobility!
Let not sloth dim your honors new begot.
Cropped are the flower-de-luces in your arms;
Of England’s coat, one half is cut away.

sp.speaker: EXETER
sp.l: Were our tears wanting to this funeral,
These tidings would call forth her flowing tides.

sp.speaker: BEDFORD
sp.l: Me they concern; regent I am of France.
Give me my steelèd coat, I’ll fight for France.
Away with these disgraceful wailing robes.
Wounds will I lend the French instead of eyes
To weep their intermissive miseries.

div.stage: Enter to them another Messenger, with papers.

sp.speaker: SECOND MESSENGER
sp.l: Lords, view these letters, full of bad mischance.
France is revolted from the English quite,
Except some petty towns of no import.
The Dauphin Charles is crownèd king in Rheims;
The Bastard of Orleance with him is joined;
Reignier, Duke of Anjou, doth take his part;
The Duke of Alanson flieth to his side.

sp.speaker: EXETER
sp.l: The Dauphin crownèd king? All fly to him?
O, whither shall we fly from this reproach?

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.l: We will not fly but to our enemies’ throats.—
Bedford, if thou be slack, I’ll fight it out.

sp.speaker: BEDFORD
sp.l: Gloucester, why doubt’st thou of my forwardness?
An army have I mustered in my thoughts,
Wherewith already France is overrun.

sp.speaker: THIRD MESSENGER
sp.l: My gracious lords, to add to your laments,
Wherewith you now bedew King Henry’s hearse,
I must inform you of a dismal fight
Betwixt the stout Lord Talbot and the French.

sp.speaker: WINCHESTER
sp.l: What? Wherein Talbot overcame, is ’t so?

sp.speaker: THIRD MESSENGER
sp.l: O no, wherein Lord Talbot was o’erthrown.
The circumstance I’ll tell you more at large.
The tenth of August last, this dreadful lord,
Retiring from the siege of Orleance,
Having full scarce six thousand in his troop,
By three and twenty thousand of the French
Was round encompassèd and set upon.
No leisure had he to enrank his men.
He wanted pikes to set before his archers,
Instead whereof, sharp stakes plucked out of hedges
They pitchèd in the ground confusedly
To keep the horsemen off from breaking in.
More than three hours the fight continuèd,
Where valiant Talbot, above human thought,
Enacted wonders with his sword and lance.
Hundreds he sent to hell, and none durst stand him;
Here, there, and everywhere, enraged, he slew.
The French exclaimed the devil was in arms;
All the whole army stood agazed on him.
His soldiers, spying his undaunted spirit,
“ À Talbot! À Talbot!” cried out amain
And rushed into the bowels of the battle.
Here had the conquest fully been sealed up
If Sir John Fastolf had not played the coward.
He, being in the vaward, placed behind
With purpose to relieve and follow them,
Cowardly fled, not having struck one stroke.
Hence grew the general wrack and massacre.
Enclosèd were they with their enemies.
A base Walloon, to win the Dauphin’s grace,
Thrust Talbot with a spear into the back,
Whom all France, with their chief assembled strength,
Durst not presume to look once in the face.

sp.speaker: BEDFORD
sp.l: Is Talbot slain then? I will slay myself
For living idly here, in pomp and ease,
Whilst such a worthy leader, wanting aid,
Unto his dastard foemen is betrayed.

sp.speaker: THIRD MESSENGER
sp.l: O, no, he lives, but is took prisoner,
And Lord Scales with him, and Lord Hungerford;
Most of the rest slaughtered or took likewise.

sp.speaker: BEDFORD
sp.l: His ransom there is none but I shall pay.
I’ll hale the Dauphin headlong from his throne;
His crown shall be the ransom of my friend.
Four of their lords I’ll change for one of ours.
Farewell, my masters; to my task will I.
Bonfires in France forthwith I am to make,
To keep our great Saint George’s feast withal.
Ten thousand soldiers with me I will take,
Whose bloody deeds shall make all Europe quake.

sp.speaker: THIRD MESSENGER
sp.l: So you had need; ’fore Orleance besieged,
The English army is grown weak and faint;
The Earl of Salisbury craveth supply
And hardly keeps his men from mutiny,
Since they so few watch such a multitude.

sp.speaker: EXETER
sp.l: Remember, lords, your oaths to Henry sworn:
Either to quell the Dauphin utterly
Or bring him in obedience to your yoke.

sp.speaker: BEDFORD
sp.l: I do remember it, and here take my leave
To go about my preparation.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.l: I’ll to the Tower with all the haste I can
To view th’ artillery and munition,
And then I will proclaim young Henry king.

sp.speaker: EXETER
sp.l: To Eltham will I, where the young king is,
Being ordained his special governor;
And for his safety there I’ll best devise.

sp.speaker: WINCHESTER
sp.l: Each hath his place and function to attend.
I am left out; for me nothing remains.
But long I will not be Jack-out-of-office.
The King from Eltham I intend to steal,
And sit at chiefest stern of public weal.

div.stage: He exits at one door; at another door, Warwick, Somerset, Attendants and Heralds exit with the coffin.

div.head: Scene 2
div.stage: Sound a flourish. Enter Charles the Dauphin, Alanson, and Reignier, marching with Drum and Soldiers.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Mars his true moving, even as in the heavens
So in the Earth, to this day is not known.
Late did he shine upon the English side;
Now we are victors; upon us he smiles.
What towns of any moment but we have?
At pleasure here we lie, near Orleance.
Otherwhiles, the famished English, like pale ghosts,
Faintly besiege us one hour in a month.

sp.speaker: ALANSON
sp.l: They want their porridge and their fat bull beeves.
Either they must be dieted like mules
And have their provender tied to their mouths,
Or piteous they will look, like drownèd mice.

sp.speaker: REIGNIER
sp.l: Let’s raise the siege. Why live we idly here?
Talbot is taken, whom we wont to fear.
Remaineth none but mad-brained Salisbury,
And he may well in fretting spend his gall;
Nor men nor money hath he to make war.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Sound, sound alarum! We will rush on them.
Now for the honor of the forlorn French!
Him I forgive my death that killeth me
When he sees me go back one foot, or fly.

stage.stage: Here alarum. They are beaten back by the English, with great loss.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Whoever saw the like? What men have I!
Dogs, cowards, dastards! I would ne’er have fled
But that they left me ’midst my enemies.

sp.speaker: REIGNIER
sp.l: Salisbury is a desperate homicide.
He fighteth as one weary of his life.
The other lords, like lions wanting food,
Do rush upon us as their hungry prey.

sp.speaker: ALANSON
sp.l: Froissart, a countryman of ours, records
England all Olivers and Rolands bred
During the time Edward the Third did reign.
More truly now may this be verified,
For none but Samsons and Goliases
It sendeth forth to skirmish. One to ten!
Lean rawboned rascals! Who would e’er suppose
They had such courage and audacity?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Let’s leave this town, for they are hare-brained slaves,
And hunger will enforce them to be more eager.
Of old I know them; rather with their teeth
The walls they’ll tear down than forsake the siege.

sp.speaker: REIGNIER
sp.l: I think by some odd gimmers or device
Their arms are set, like clocks, still to strike on;
Else ne’er could they hold out so as they do.
By my consent, we’ll even let them alone.

sp.speaker: ALANSON
sp.l: Be it so.

sp.speaker: BASTARD
sp.l: Where’s the Prince Dauphin? I have news for him.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Bastard of Orleance, thrice welcome to us.

sp.speaker: BASTARD
sp.l: Methinks your looks are sad, your cheer appalled.
Hath the late overthrow wrought this offence?
Be not dismayed, for succor is at hand.
A holy maid hither with me I bring,
Which, by a vision sent to her from heaven,
Ordainèd is to raise this tedious siege
And drive the English forth the bounds of France.
The spirit of deep prophecy she hath,
Exceeding the nine Sibyls of old Rome.
What’s past and what’s to come she can descry.
Speak, shall I call her in? Believe my words,
For they are certain and unfallible.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Go call her in.
But first, to try her skill,
Reignier, stand thou as Dauphin in my place;
Question her proudly; let thy looks be stern.
By this means shall we sound what skill she hath.

div.stage: Enter Bastard, with Joan la Pucelle.

sp.speaker: REIGNIER
sp.l: Fair maid, is ’t thou wilt do these wondrous feats?

sp.speaker: PUCELLE
sp.l: Reignier, is ’t thou that thinkest to beguile me?
Where is the Dauphin?— Come, come from behind.
I know thee well, though never seen before.
Be not amazed; there’s nothing hid from me.
In private will I talk with thee apart.—
Stand back, you lords, and give us leave a while.

sp.speaker: REIGNIER
sp.l: She takes upon her bravely at first dash.

sp.speaker: PUCELLE
sp.l: Dauphin, I am by birth a shepherd’s daughter,
My wit untrained in any kind of art.
Heaven and Our Lady gracious hath it pleased
To shine on my contemptible estate.
Lo, whilst I waited on my tender lambs,
And to sun’s parching heat displayed my cheeks,
God’s Mother deignèd to appear to me,
And in a vision full of majesty
Willed me to leave my base vocation
And free my country from calamity.
Her aid she promised and assured success.
In complete glory she revealed herself;
And whereas I was black and swart before,
With those clear rays which she infused on me
That beauty am I blest with, which you may see.
Ask me what question thou canst possible,
And I will answer unpremeditated.
My courage try by combat, if thou dar’st,
And thou shalt find that I exceed my sex.
Resolve on this: thou shalt be fortunate
If thou receive me for thy warlike mate.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Thou hast astonished me with thy high terms.
Only this proof I’ll of thy valor make:
In single combat thou shalt buckle with me,
And if thou vanquishest, thy words are true;
Otherwise I renounce all confidence.

sp.speaker: PUCELLE
sp.l: I am prepared. Here is my keen-edged sword,
Decked with fine flower-de-luces on each side—
Aside. The which at Touraine, in Saint Katherine’s churchyard,
Out of a great deal of old iron I chose forth.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Then come, a’ God’s name! I fear no woman.

sp.speaker: PUCELLE
sp.l: And while I live, I’ll ne’er fly from a man.

div.stage: Here they fight, and Joan la Pucelle overcomes.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Stay, stay thy hands! Thou art an Amazon,
And fightest with the sword of Deborah.

sp.speaker: PUCELLE
sp.l: Christ’s mother helps me; else I were too weak.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Whoe’er helps thee, ’tis thou that must help me.
Impatiently I burn with thy desire.
My heart and hands thou hast at once subdued.
Excellent Pucelle, if thy name be so,
Let me thy servant and not sovereign be.
’Tis the French Dauphin sueth to thee thus.

sp.speaker: PUCELLE
sp.l: I must not yield to any rights of love,
For my profession’s sacred from above.
When I have chasèd all thy foes from hence,
Then will I think upon a recompense.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Meantime look gracious on thy prostrate thrall.

sp.speaker: REIGNIER
sp.l: My lord, methinks, is very long in talk.

sp.speaker: ALANSON
sp.l: Doubtless he shrives this woman to her smock,
Else ne’er could he so long protract his speech.

sp.speaker: REIGNIER
sp.l: Shall we disturb him, since he keeps no mean?

sp.speaker: ALANSON
sp.l: He may mean more than we poor men do know.
These women are shrewd tempters with their tongues.

sp.speaker: REIGNIER
sp.l: My lord, where are you? What devise you on?
Shall we give o’er Orleance, or no?

sp.speaker: PUCELLE
sp.l: Why, no, I say. Distrustful recreants,
Fight till the last gasp. I’ll be your guard.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: What she says I’ll confirm: we’ll fight it out.

sp.speaker: PUCELLE
sp.l: Assigned am I to be the English scourge.
This night the siege assuredly I’ll raise.
Expect Saint Martin’s summer, halcyons’ days,
Since I have enterèd into these wars.
Glory is like a circle in the water,
Which never ceaseth to enlarge itself
Till by broad spreading it disperse to naught.
With Henry’s death, the English circle ends;
Dispersèd are the glories it included.
Now am I like that proud insulting ship
Which Caesar and his fortune bare at once.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Was Mahomet inspirèd with a dove?
Thou with an eagle art inspirèd then.
Helen, the mother of great Constantine,
Nor yet Saint Philip’s daughters were like thee.
Bright star of Venus, fall’n down on the Earth,
How may I reverently worship thee enough?

sp.speaker: ALANSON
sp.l: Leave off delays, and let us raise the siege.

sp.speaker: REIGNIER
sp.l: Woman, do what thou canst to save our honors.
Drive them from Orleance and be immortalized.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Presently we’ll try. Come, let’s away about it.
No prophet will I trust if she prove false.

div.head: Scene 3
div.stage: Enter Gloucester with his Servingmen in blue coats.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.l: I am come to survey the Tower this day.
Since Henry’s death I fear there is conveyance.
Where be these warders that they wait not here?—
Open the gates! ’Tis Gloucester that calls.

sp.speaker: FIRST WARDER
sp.l: Who’s there that knocks so imperiously?

sp.speaker: FIRST SERVINGMAN
sp.l: It is the noble Duke of Gloucester.

sp.speaker: SECOND WARDER
sp.l: Whoe’er he be, you may not be let in.

sp.speaker: FIRST SERVINGMAN
sp.l: Villains, answer you so the Lord Protector?

sp.speaker: FIRST WARDER
sp.l: The Lord protect him, so we answer him.
We do no otherwise than we are willed.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.l: Who willed you? Or whose will stands but mine?
There’s none Protector of the realm but I.—
Break up the gates! I’ll be your warrantize.
Shall I be flouted thus by dunghill grooms?

div.stage: Gloucester’s men rush at the Tower gates, and Woodville, the lieutenant, speaks within.

sp.speaker: WOODVILLE
sp.l: What noise is this? What traitors have we here?

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.l: Lieutenant, is it you whose voice I hear?
Open the gates. Here’s Gloucester that would enter.

sp.speaker: WOODVILLE
sp.l: Have patience, noble duke, I may not open.
The Cardinal of Winchester forbids.
From him I have express commandment
That thou nor none of thine shall be let in.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.l: Fainthearted Woodville, prizest him ’fore me?
Arrogant Winchester, that haughty prelate
Whom Henry, our late sovereign, ne’er could brook?
Thou art no friend to God or to the King.
Open the gates, or I’ll shut thee out shortly.

sp.speaker: SERVINGMEN
sp.l: Open the gates unto the Lord Protector,
Or we’ll burst them open if that you come not quickly.

div.stage: Enter, to the Protector at the Tower gates, Winchester in cardinal’s robes and his men in tawny coats.

sp.speaker: WINCHESTER
sp.l: How now, ambitious Humphrey, what means this?

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.l: Peeled priest, dost thou command me to be shut out?

sp.speaker: WINCHESTER
sp.l: I do, thou most usurping proditor—
And not Protector— of the King or realm.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.l: Stand back, thou manifest conspirator,
Thou that contrived’st to murder our dead lord,
Thou that giv’st whores indulgences to sin!
I’ll canvass thee in thy broad cardinal’s hat
If thou proceed in this thy insolence.

sp.speaker: WINCHESTER
sp.l: Nay, stand thou back. I will not budge a foot.
This be Damascus; be thou cursèd Cain
To slay thy brother Abel, if thou wilt.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.l: I will not slay thee, but I’ll drive thee back.
Thy scarlet robes, as a child’s bearing-cloth,
I’ll use to carry thee out of this place.

sp.speaker: WINCHESTER
sp.l: Do what thou dar’st, I beard thee to thy face.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.l: What, am I dared and bearded to my face?—
Draw, men, for all this privilegèd place.
Blue coats to tawny coats!
Priest, beware your beard.
I mean to tug it and to cuff you soundly.
Under my feet I’ll stamp thy cardinal’s hat;
In spite of pope or dignities of Church,
Here by the cheeks I’ll drag thee up and down.

sp.speaker: WINCHESTER
sp.l: Gloucester, thou wilt answer this before the Pope.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.l: Winchester goose, I cry “ a rope, a rope!”—
Now beat them hence; why do you let them stay?—
Thee I’ll chase hence, thou wolf in sheep’s array.—
Out, tawny coats, out, scarlet hypocrite!

div.stage: Here Gloucester’s men beat out the Cardinal’s men, and enter in the hurly-burly the Mayor of London and his Officers.

sp.speaker: MAYOR
sp.l: Fie, lords, that you, being supreme magistrates,
Thus contumeliously should break the peace!

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.l: Peace, Mayor? Thou know’st little of my wrongs.
Here’s Beaufort, that regards nor God nor king,
Hath here distrained the Tower to his use.

sp.speaker: WINCHESTER
sp.l: Here’s Gloucester, a foe to citizens,
One that still motions war and never peace,
O’ercharging your free purses with large fines;
That seeks to overthrow religion
Because he is Protector of the realm,
And would have armor here out of the Tower
To crown himself king and suppress the Prince.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.l: I will not answer thee with words, but blows.

sp.speaker: MAYOR
sp.l: Naught rests for me in this tumultuous strife
But to make open proclamation.
Come, officer, as loud as e’er thou canst, cry.

div.stage: He hands an Officer a paper.

p.q:
All manner of men, assembled here in
arms this day against God’s peace and the King’s, we
charge and command you, in his Highness’ name, to
repair to your several dwelling places, and not to
wear, handle, or use any sword, weapon, or dagger
henceforward, upon pain of death.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.l: Cardinal, I’ll be no breaker of the law,
But we shall meet and break our minds at large.

sp.speaker: WINCHESTER
sp.l: Gloucester, we’ll meet to thy cost, be sure.
Thy heartblood I will have for this day’s work.

sp.speaker: MAYOR
sp.l: I’ll call for clubs if you will not away.
( Aside.) This cardinal’s more haughty than the devil!

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.l: Mayor, farewell. Thou dost but what thou mayst.

sp.speaker: WINCHESTER
sp.l: Abominable Gloucester, guard thy head,
For I intend to have it ere long.

div.stage: Gloucester and Winchester exit at separate doors, with their Servingmen.

sp.speaker: MAYOR
sp.l: See the coast cleared, and then we will depart.
( Aside.) Good God, these nobles should such stomachs bear!
I myself fight not once in forty year.

div.head: Scene 4
div.stage: Enter the Master Gunner of Orleance and his Boy.

sp.speaker: MASTER GUNNER
sp.l: Sirrah, thou know’st how Orleance is besieged
And how the English have the suburbs won.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.l: Father, I know, and oft have shot at them;
Howe’er, unfortunate, I missed my aim.

sp.speaker: MASTER GUNNER
sp.l: But now thou shalt not. Be thou ruled by me.
Chief master-gunner am I of this town;
Something I must do to procure me grace.
The Prince’s espials have informèd me
How the English, in the suburbs close entrenched,
Went through a secret grate of iron bars
In yonder tower, to overpeer the city,
And thence discover how with most advantage
They may vex us with shot or with assault.
To intercept this inconvenience,
A piece of ordnance ’gainst it I have placed,
And even these three days have I watched
If I could see them. Now do thou watch,
For I can stay no longer.
If thou spy’st any, run and bring me word;
And thou shalt find me at the Governor’s.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.l: Father, I warrant you, take you no care;
I’ll never trouble you if I may spy them.

div.stage: Enter Salisbury and Talbot on the turrets, with Sir William Glansdale, Sir Thomas Gargrave, Attendants and Others.

sp.speaker: SALISBURY
sp.l: Talbot, my life, my joy, again returned!
How wert thou handled, being prisoner?
Or by what means gott’st thou to be released?
Discourse, I prithee, on this turret’s top.

sp.speaker: TALBOT
sp.l: The Duke of Bedford had a prisoner
Called the brave Lord Ponton de Santrailles;
For him was I exchanged and ransomèd.
But with a baser man-of-arms by far
Once in contempt they would have bartered me,
Which I disdaining, scorned, and cravèd death
Rather than I would be so vile-esteemed.
In fine, redeemed I was as I desired.
But O, the treacherous Fastolf wounds my heart,
Whom with my bare fists I would execute
If I now had him brought into my power.

sp.speaker: SALISBURY
sp.l: Yet tell’st thou not how thou wert entertained.

sp.speaker: TALBOT
sp.l: With scoffs and scorns and contumelious taunts.
In open marketplace produced they me
To be a public spectacle to all.
“ Here,” said they, “ is the terror of the French,
The scarecrow that affrights our children so.”
Then broke I from the officers that led me,
And with my nails digged stones out of the ground
To hurl at the beholders of my shame.
My grisly countenance made others fly;
None durst come near for fear of sudden death.
In iron walls they deemed me not secure:
So great fear of my name ’mongst them were spread
That they supposed I could rend bars of steel
And spurn in pieces posts of adamant.
Wherefore a guard of chosen shot I had
That walked about me every minute-while;
And if I did but stir out of my bed,
Ready they were to shoot me to the heart.

div.stage: Enter the Boy with a linstock. He crosses the main stage and exits.

sp.speaker: SALISBURY
sp.l: I grieve to hear what torments you endured,
But we will be revenged sufficiently.
Now it is supper time in Orleance.
Here, through this grate, I count each one
And view the Frenchmen how they fortify.
Let us look in; the sight will much delight thee.
Sir Thomas Gargrave and Sir William Glansdale,
Let me have your express opinions
Where is best place to make our batt’ry next?

sp.speaker: GARGRAVE
sp.l: I think at the north gate, for there stands lords.

sp.speaker: GLANSDALE
sp.l: And I, here, at the bulwark of the bridge.

sp.speaker: TALBOT
sp.l: For aught I see, this city must be famished
Or with light skirmishes enfeeblèd.

div.stage: Here they shoot, and Salisbury and Gargrave fall down.

sp.speaker: SALISBURY
sp.l: O Lord, have mercy on us, wretched sinners!

sp.speaker: GARGRAVE
sp.l: O Lord, have mercy on me, woeful man!

sp.speaker: TALBOT
sp.l: What chance is this that suddenly hath crossed us?—
Speak, Salisbury— at least if thou canst, speak!
How far’st thou, mirror of all martial men?
One of thy eyes and thy cheek’s side struck off!—
Accursèd tower, accursèd fatal hand
That hath contrived this woeful tragedy!
In thirteen battles Salisbury o’ercame;
Henry the Fifth he first trained to the wars.
Whilst any trump did sound or drum struck up,
His sword did ne’er leave striking in the field.—
Yet liv’st thou, Salisbury? Though thy speech doth fail,
One eye thou hast to look to heaven for grace.
The sun with one eye vieweth all the world.
Heaven, be thou gracious to none alive
If Salisbury wants mercy at thy hands!—
Sir Thomas Gargrave, hast thou any life?
Speak unto Talbot. Nay, look up to him.—
Bear hence his body; I will help to bury it.
sp.stage: Attendants exit with body of Gargrave.
sp.l: Salisbury, cheer thy spirit with this comfort,
Thou shalt not die whiles—
He beckons with his hand and smiles on me
As who should say “ When I am dead and gone,
Remember to avenge me on the French.”
Plantagenet, I will; and, like thee, Nero,
Play on the lute, beholding the towns burn.
Wretched shall France be only in my name.
sp.stage: Here an alarum, and it thunders and lightens.
sp.l: What stir is this? What tumult’s in the heavens?
Whence cometh this alarum and the noise?

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: My lord, my lord, the French have gathered head.
The Dauphin, with one Joan la Pucelle joined,
A holy prophetess new risen up,
Is come with a great power to raise the siege.

div.stage: Here Salisbury lifteth himself up and groans.

sp.speaker: TALBOT
sp.l: Hear, hear, how dying Salisbury doth groan;
It irks his heart he cannot be revenged.
Frenchmen, I’ll be a Salisbury to you.
Pucelle or puzel, dauphin or dogfish,
Your hearts I’ll stamp out with my horse’s heels
And make a quagmire of your mingled brains.
Convey we Salisbury into his tent,
And then try what these dastard Frenchmen dare.

stage.stage: Here an alarum again, and Talbot pursueth the Dauphin and driveth him; then enter Joan la Pucelle, driving Englishmen before her. They cross the stage and exit.

sp.speaker: TALBOT
sp.l: Where is my strength, my valor, and my force?
Our English troops retire; I cannot stay them.
A woman clad in armor chaseth them.
Here, here she comes!— I’ll have a bout with thee.
Devil or devil’s dam, I’ll conjure thee.
Blood will I draw on thee— thou art a witch—
And straightway give thy soul to him thou serv’st.

sp.speaker: PUCELLE
sp.l: Come, come; ’tis only I that must disgrace thee.

sp.speaker: TALBOT
sp.l: Heavens, can you suffer hell so to prevail?
My breast I’ll burst with straining of my courage,
And from my shoulders crack my arms asunder,
But I will chastise this high-minded strumpet.

sp.speaker: PUCELLE
sp.l: Talbot, farewell. Thy hour is not yet come.
I must go victual Orleance forthwith.
sp.stage: A short alarum. Then she prepares to enter the town with Soldiers.
sp.l: O’ertake me if thou canst. I scorn thy strength.
Go, go, cheer up thy hunger-starvèd men.
Help Salisbury to make his testament.
This day is ours, as many more shall be.

sp.speaker: TALBOT
sp.l: My thoughts are whirlèd like a potter’s wheel.
I know not where I am nor what I do.
A witch by fear— not force, like Hannibal—
Drives back our troops, and conquers as she lists.
So bees with smoke and doves with noisome stench
Are from their hives and houses driven away.
They called us, for our fierceness, English dogs;
Now like to whelps we crying run away.
sp.stage: A short alarum. Enter English soldiers, chased by French soldiers.
sp.l: Hark, countrymen, either renew the fight,
Or tear the lions out of England’s coat.
Renounce your soil; give sheep in lions’ stead.
Sheep run not half so treacherous from the wolf,
Or horse or oxen from the leopard,
As you fly from your oft-subduèd slaves.
It will not be! Retire into your trenches.
You all consented unto Salisbury’s death,
For none would strike a stroke in his revenge.
Pucelle is entered into Orleance
In spite of us or aught that we could do.
O, would I were to die with Salisbury!
The shame hereof will make me hide my head.

div.head: Scene 6
div.stage: Flourish. Enter on the walls Pucelle, Charles the Dauphin, Reignier, Alanson, and Soldiers.

sp.speaker: PUCELLE
sp.l: Advance our waving colors on the walls.
Rescued is Orleance from the English.
Thus Joan la Pucelle hath performed her word.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Divinest creature, Astraea’s daughter,
How shall I honor thee for this success?
Thy promises are like Adonis’ garden
That one day bloomed and fruitful were the next.
France, triumph in thy glorious prophetess.
Recovered is the town of Orleance.
More blessèd hap did ne’er befall our state.

sp.speaker: REIGNIER
sp.l: Why ring not bells aloud throughout the town?
Dauphin, command the citizens make bonfires
And feast and banquet in the open streets
To celebrate the joy that God hath given us.

sp.speaker: ALANSON
sp.l: All France will be replete with mirth and joy
When they shall hear how we have played the men.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: ’Tis Joan, not we, by whom the day is won;
For which I will divide my crown with her,
And all the priests and friars in my realm
Shall in procession sing her endless praise.
A statelier pyramis to her I’ll rear
Than Rhodophe’s of Memphis ever was.
In memory of her, when she is dead,
Her ashes, in an urn more precious
Than the rich-jeweled coffer of Darius,
Transported shall be at high festivals
Before the kings and queens of France.
No longer on Saint Dennis will we cry,
But Joan la Pucelle shall be France’s saint.
Come in, and let us banquet royally
After this golden day of victory.

div.head: Scene 1
div.stage: Enter on the walls a French Sergeant of a Band, with two Sentinels.

sp.speaker: SERGEANT
sp.l: Sirs, take your places and be vigilant.
If any noise or soldier you perceive
Near to the walls, by some apparent sign
Let us have knowledge at the court of guard.

sp.speaker: SENTINEL
sp.l: Sergeant, you shall.
Thus are poor servitors,
When others sleep upon their quiet beds,
Constrained to watch in darkness, rain, and cold.

div.stage: Enter Talbot, Bedford, and Burgundy, below, with scaling ladders.

sp.speaker: TALBOT
sp.l: Lord Regent, and redoubted Burgundy,
By whose approach the regions of Artois,
Walloon, and Picardy are friends to us,
This happy night the Frenchmen are secure,
Having all day caroused and banqueted.
Embrace we then this opportunity,
As fitting best to quittance their deceit
Contrived by art and baleful sorcery.

sp.speaker: BEDFORD
sp.l: Coward of France, how much he wrongs his fame,
Despairing of his own arm’s fortitude,
To join with witches and the help of hell!

sp.speaker: BURGUNDY
sp.l: Traitors have never other company.
But what’s that Pucelle whom they term so pure?

sp.speaker: TALBOT
sp.l: A maid, they say.

sp.speaker: BEDFORD
sp.l: A maid? And be so martial?

sp.speaker: BURGUNDY
sp.l: Pray God she prove not masculine ere long,
If underneath the standard of the French
She carry armor as she hath begun.

sp.speaker: TALBOT
sp.l: Well, let them practice and converse with spirits.
God is our fortress, in whose conquering name
Let us resolve to scale their flinty bulwarks.

sp.speaker: BEDFORD
sp.l: Ascend, brave Talbot. We will follow thee.

sp.speaker: TALBOT
sp.l: Not all together. Better far, I guess,
That we do make our entrance several ways,
That if it chance the one of us do fail,
The other yet may rise against their force.

sp.speaker: BEDFORD
sp.l: Agreed. I’ll to yond corner.

sp.speaker: BURGUNDY
sp.l: And I to this.

sp.speaker: TALBOT
sp.l: And here will Talbot mount, or make his grave.
Now, Salisbury, for thee and for the right
Of English Henry, shall this night appear
How much in duty I am bound to both.

div.stage: Scaling the walls, they cry“ Saint George! À Talbot!”

sp.speaker: SENTINEL
sp.l: Arm, arm! The enemy doth make assault.

div.stage: The English, pursuing the Sentinels, exit aloft.
The French leap o’er the walls in their shirts.
Enter several ways, Bastard, Alanson, Reignier, half ready, and half unready.

sp.speaker: ALANSON
sp.l: How now, my lords? What, all unready so?

sp.speaker: BASTARD
sp.l: Unready? Ay, and glad we scaped so well.

sp.speaker: REIGNIER
sp.l: ’Twas time, I trow, to wake and leave our beds,
Hearing alarums at our chamber doors.

sp.speaker: ALANSON
sp.l: Of all exploits since first I followed arms
Ne’er heard I of a warlike enterprise
More venturous or desperate than this.

sp.speaker: BASTARD
sp.l: I think this Talbot be a fiend of hell.

sp.speaker: REIGNIER
sp.l: If not of hell, the heavens sure favor him.

sp.speaker: ALANSON
sp.l: Here cometh Charles. I marvel how he sped.

div.stage: Enter Charles and Joan la Pucelle.

sp.speaker: BASTARD
sp.l: Tut, holy Joan was his defensive guard.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Is this thy cunning, thou deceitful dame?
Didst thou at first, to flatter us withal,
Make us partakers of a little gain
That now our loss might be ten times so much?

sp.speaker: PUCELLE
sp.l: Wherefore is Charles impatient with his friend?
At all times will you have my power alike?
Sleeping or waking, must I still prevail,
Or will you blame and lay the fault on me?—
Improvident soldiers, had your watch been good,
This sudden mischief never could have fall’n.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Duke of Alanson, this was your default,
That, being captain of the watch tonight,
Did look no better to that weighty charge.

sp.speaker: ALANSON
sp.l: Had all your quarters been as safely kept
As that whereof I had the government,
We had not been thus shamefully surprised.

sp.speaker: BASTARD
sp.l: Mine was secure.

sp.speaker: REIGNIER
sp.l: And so was mine, my lord.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: And for myself, most part of all this night
Within her quarter and mine own precinct
I was employed in passing to and fro
About relieving of the sentinels.
Then how or which way should they first break in?

sp.speaker: PUCELLE
sp.l: Question, my lords, no further of the case,
How or which way; ’tis sure they found some place
But weakly guarded, where the breach was made.
And now there rests no other shift but this:
To gather our soldiers, scattered and dispersed,
And lay new platforms to endamage them.

stage.stage: Alarum. Enter an English Soldier, crying,“ À Talbot, À Talbot!”
The French fly, leaving their clothes behind.

sp.speaker: SOLDIER
sp.l: I’ll be so bold to take what they have left.
The cry of “ Talbot” serves me for a sword,
For I have loaden me with many spoils,
Using no other weapon but his name.

div.head: Scene 2
div.stage: Enter Talbot, Bedford, Burgundy, a Captain and Others.

sp.speaker: BEDFORD
sp.l: The day begins to break and night is fled,
Whose pitchy mantle over-veiled the Earth.
Here sound retreat and cease our hot pursuit.

sp.speaker: TALBOT
sp.l: Bring forth the body of old Salisbury,
And here advance it in the marketplace,
The middle center of this cursèd town.
sp.stage: Soldiers enter bearing the body of Salisbury, Drums beating a dead march.
sp.l: Now have I paid my vow unto his soul:
For every drop of blood was drawn from him
There hath at least five Frenchmen died tonight.
And, that hereafter ages may behold
What ruin happened in revenge of him,
Within their chiefest temple I’ll erect
A tomb wherein his corpse shall be interred,
Upon the which, that everyone may read,
Shall be engraved the sack of Orleance,
The treacherous manner of his mournful death,
And what a terror he had been to France.
But, lords, in all our bloody massacre,
I muse we met not with the Dauphin’s grace,
His new-come champion, virtuous Joan of Arc,
Nor any of his false confederates.

sp.speaker: BEDFORD
sp.l: ’Tis thought, Lord Talbot, when the fight began,
Roused on the sudden from their drowsy beds,
They did amongst the troops of armèd men
Leap o’er the walls for refuge in the field.

sp.speaker: BURGUNDY
sp.l: Myself, as far as I could well discern
For smoke and dusky vapors of the night,
Am sure I scared the Dauphin and his trull,
When arm-in-arm they both came swiftly running,
Like to a pair of loving turtledoves
That could not live asunder day or night.
After that things are set in order here,
We’ll follow them with all the power we have.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: All hail, my lords. Which of this princely train
Call you the warlike Talbot, for his acts
So much applauded through the realm of France?

sp.speaker: TALBOT
sp.l: Here is the Talbot. Who would speak with him?

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: The virtuous lady, Countess of Auvergne,
With modesty admiring thy renown,
By me entreats, great lord, thou wouldst vouchsafe
To visit her poor castle where she lies,
That she may boast she hath beheld the man
Whose glory fills the world with loud report.

sp.speaker: BURGUNDY
sp.l: Is it even so? Nay, then, I see our wars
Will turn unto a peaceful comic sport,
When ladies crave to be encountered with.
You may not, my lord, despise her gentle suit.

sp.speaker: TALBOT
sp.l: Ne’er trust me, then; for when a world of men
Could not prevail with all their oratory,
Yet hath a woman’s kindness overruled.—
And therefore tell her I return great thanks,
And in submission will attend on her.—
Will not your Honors bear me company?

sp.speaker: BEDFORD
sp.l: No, truly, ’tis more than manners will;
And I have heard it said unbidden guests
Are often welcomest when they are gone.

sp.speaker: TALBOT
sp.l: Well then, alone, since there’s no remedy,
I mean to prove this lady’s courtesy.—
Come hither, captain.
You perceive my mind?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.l: I do, my lord, and mean accordingly.

div.head: Scene 3
div.stage: Enter Countess of Auvergne, with Porter.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: Porter, remember what I gave in charge,
And when you have done so, bring the keys to me.

sp.speaker: PORTER
sp.l: Madam, I will.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: The plot is laid. If all things fall out right,
I shall as famous be by this exploit
As Scythian Tamyris by Cyrus’ death.
Great is the rumor of this dreadful knight,
And his achievements of no less account.
Fain would mine eyes be witness with mine ears
To give their censure of these rare reports.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: Madam, according as your Ladyship desired,
By message craved, so is Lord Talbot come.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: And he is welcome. What, is this the man?

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: Madam, it is.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: Is this the scourge of France?
Is this the Talbot, so much feared abroad
That with his name the mothers still their babes?
I see report is fabulous and false.
I thought I should have seen some Hercules,
A second Hector, for his grim aspect
And large proportion of his strong-knit limbs.
Alas, this is a child, a silly dwarf!
It cannot be this weak and writhled shrimp
Should strike such terror to his enemies.

sp.speaker: TALBOT
sp.l: Madam, I have been bold to trouble you.
But since your Ladyship is not at leisure,
I’ll sort some other time to visit you.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: What means he now? Go ask him whither he goes.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: Stay, my Lord Talbot, for my lady craves
To know the cause of your abrupt departure.

sp.speaker: TALBOT
sp.l: Marry, for that she’s in a wrong belief,
I go to certify her Talbot’s here.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: If thou be he, then art thou prisoner.

sp.speaker: TALBOT
sp.l: Prisoner? To whom?

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: To me, bloodthirsty lord.
And for that cause I trained thee to my house.
Long time thy shadow hath been thrall to me,
For in my gallery thy picture hangs.
But now the substance shall endure the like,
And I will chain these legs and arms of thine,
That hast by tyranny these many years
Wasted our country, slain our citizens,
And sent our sons and husbands captivate.

sp.speaker: TALBOT
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: Laughest thou, wretch? Thy mirth shall turn to moan.

sp.speaker: TALBOT
sp.l: I laugh to see your Ladyship so fond
To think that you have aught but Talbot’s shadow
Whereon to practice your severity.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: Why, art not thou the man?

sp.speaker: TALBOT
sp.l: I am, indeed.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: Then have I substance too.

sp.speaker: TALBOT
sp.l: No, no, I am but shadow of myself.
You are deceived; my substance is not here,
For what you see is but the smallest part
And least proportion of humanity.
I tell you, madam, were the whole frame here,
It is of such a spacious lofty pitch
Your roof were not sufficient to contain ’t.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: This is a riddling merchant for the nonce:
He will be here and yet he is not here.
How can these contrarieties agree?

sp.speaker: TALBOT
sp.l: That will I show you presently.

stage.stage: Drums strike up; a peal of ordnance.

sp.l: How say you, madam? Are you now persuaded
That Talbot is but shadow of himself?
These are his substance, sinews, arms, and strength,
With which he yoketh your rebellious necks,
Razeth your cities, and subverts your towns,
And in a moment makes them desolate.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: Victorious Talbot, pardon my abuse.
I find thou art no less than fame hath bruited,
And more than may be gathered by thy shape.
Let my presumption not provoke thy wrath,
For I am sorry that with reverence
I did not entertain thee as thou art.

sp.speaker: TALBOT
sp.l: Be not dismayed, fair lady, nor misconster
The mind of Talbot as you did mistake
The outward composition of his body.
What you have done hath not offended me,
Nor other satisfaction do I crave
But only, with your patience, that we may
Taste of your wine and see what cates you have,
For soldiers’ stomachs always serve them well.

sp.speaker: COUNTESS
sp.l: With all my heart, and think me honorèd
To feast so great a warrior in my house.

div.head: Scene 4
div.stage: Enter Richard Plantagenet, Warwick, Somerset, William de la Pole the Earl of Suffolk, Vernon, a Lawyer, and Others.

sp.speaker: PLANTAGENET
sp.l: Great lords and gentlemen, what means this silence?
Dare no man answer in a case of truth?

sp.speaker: SUFFOLK
sp.l: Within the Temple Hall we were too loud;
The garden here is more convenient.

sp.speaker: PLANTAGENET
sp.l: Then say at once if I maintained the truth,
Or else was wrangling Somerset in th’ error?

sp.speaker: SUFFOLK
sp.l: Faith, I have been a truant in the law
And never yet could frame my will to it,
And therefore frame the law unto my will.

sp.speaker: SOMERSET
sp.l: Judge you, my Lord of Warwick, then, between us.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: Between two hawks, which flies the higher pitch,
Between two dogs, which hath the deeper mouth,
Between two blades, which bears the better temper,
Between two horses, which doth bear him best,
Between two girls, which hath the merriest eye,
I have perhaps some shallow spirit of judgment;
But in these nice sharp quillets of the law,
Good faith, I am no wiser than a daw.

sp.speaker: PLANTAGENET
sp.l: Tut, tut, here is a mannerly forbearance!
The truth appears so naked on my side
That any purblind eye may find it out.

sp.speaker: SOMERSET
sp.l: And on my side it is so well appareled,
So clear, so shining, and so evident,
That it will glimmer through a blind man’s eye.

sp.speaker: PLANTAGENET
sp.l: Since you are tongue-tied and so loath to speak,
In dumb significants proclaim your thoughts:
Let him that is a trueborn gentleman
And stands upon the honor of his birth,
If he suppose that I have pleaded truth,
From off this brier pluck a white rose with me.

sp.speaker: SOMERSET
sp.l: Let him that is no coward nor no flatterer,
But dare maintain the party of the truth,
Pluck a red rose from off this thorn with me.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: I love no colors; and, without all color
Of base insinuating flattery,
I pluck this white rose with Plantagenet.

sp.speaker: SUFFOLK
sp.l: I pluck this red rose with young Somerset,
And say withal I think he held the right.

sp.speaker: VERNON
sp.l: Stay, lords and gentlemen, and pluck no more
Till you conclude that he upon whose side
The fewest roses are croppèd from the tree
Shall yield the other in the right opinion.

sp.speaker: SOMERSET
sp.l: Good Master Vernon, it is well objected:
If I have fewest, I subscribe in silence.

sp.speaker: PLANTAGENET
sp.l: And I.

sp.speaker: VERNON
sp.l: Then for the truth and plainness of the case,
I pluck this pale and maiden blossom here,
Giving my verdict on the white rose side.

sp.speaker: SOMERSET
sp.l: Prick not your finger as you pluck it off,
Lest, bleeding, you do paint the white rose red,
And fall on my side so against your will.

sp.speaker: VERNON
sp.l: If I, my lord, for my opinion bleed,
Opinion shall be surgeon to my hurt
And keep me on the side where still I am.

sp.speaker: SOMERSET
sp.l: Well, well, come on, who else?

sp.speaker: LAWYER
sp.l: Unless my study and my books be false,
The argument you held was wrong in law,
In sign whereof I pluck a white rose too.

sp.speaker: PLANTAGENET
sp.l: Now, Somerset, where is your argument?

sp.speaker: SOMERSET
sp.l: Here in my scabbard, meditating that
Shall dye your white rose in a bloody red.

sp.speaker: PLANTAGENET
sp.l: Meantime your cheeks do counterfeit our roses,
For pale they look with fear, as witnessing
The truth on our side.

sp.speaker: SOMERSET
sp.l: No, Plantagenet.
’Tis not for fear, but anger that thy cheeks
Blush for pure shame to counterfeit our roses,
And yet thy tongue will not confess thy error.

sp.speaker: PLANTAGENET
sp.l: Hath not thy rose a canker, Somerset?

sp.speaker: SOMERSET
sp.l: Hath not thy rose a thorn, Plantagenet?

sp.speaker: PLANTAGENET
sp.l: Ay, sharp and piercing, to maintain his truth,
Whiles thy consuming canker eats his falsehood.

sp.speaker: SOMERSET
sp.l: Well, I’ll find friends to wear my bleeding roses
That shall maintain what I have said is true,
Where false Plantagenet dare not be seen.

sp.speaker: PLANTAGENET
sp.l: Now, by this maiden blossom in my hand,
I scorn thee and thy fashion, peevish boy.

sp.speaker: SUFFOLK
sp.l: Turn not thy scorns this way, Plantagenet.

sp.speaker: PLANTAGENET
sp.l: Proud Pole, I will, and scorn both him and thee.

sp.speaker: SUFFOLK
sp.l: I’ll turn my part thereof into thy throat.

sp.speaker: SOMERSET
sp.l: Away, away, good William de la Pole!
We grace the yeoman by conversing with him.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: Now, by God’s will, thou wrong’st him, Somerset.
His grandfather was Lionel, Duke of Clarence,
Third son to the third Edward, King of England.
Spring crestless yeomen from so deep a root?

sp.speaker: PLANTAGENET
sp.l: He bears him on the place’s privilege,
Or durst not for his craven heart say thus.

sp.speaker: SOMERSET
sp.l: By Him that made me, I’ll maintain my words
On any plot of ground in Christendom.
Was not thy father Richard, Earl of Cambridge,
For treason executed in our late king’s days?
And, by his treason, stand’st not thou attainted,
Corrupted, and exempt from ancient gentry?
His trespass yet lives guilty in thy blood,
And, till thou be restored, thou art a yeoman.

sp.speaker: PLANTAGENET
sp.l: My father was attachèd, not attainted,
Condemned to die for treason, but no traitor;
And that I’ll prove on better men than Somerset,
Were growing time once ripened to my will.
For your partaker Pole and you yourself,
I’ll note you in my book of memory
To scourge you for this apprehension.
Look to it well, and say you are well warned.

sp.speaker: SOMERSET
sp.l: Ah, thou shalt find us ready for thee still,
And know us by these colors for thy foes,
For these my friends in spite of thee shall wear.

sp.speaker: PLANTAGENET
sp.l: And, by my soul, this pale and angry rose,
As cognizance of my blood-drinking hate,
Will I forever, and my faction, wear
Until it wither with me to my grave
Or flourish to the height of my degree.

sp.speaker: SUFFOLK
sp.l: Go forward, and be choked with thy ambition!
And so farewell, until I meet thee next.

sp.speaker: SOMERSET
sp.l: Have with thee, Pole.— Farewell, ambitious Richard.

sp.speaker: PLANTAGENET
sp.l: How I am braved, and must perforce endure it!

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: This blot that they object against your house
Shall be whipped out in the next parliament,
Called for the truce of Winchester and Gloucester;
And if thou be not then created York,
I will not live to be accounted Warwick.
Meantime, in signal of my love to thee,
Against proud Somerset and William Pole
Will I upon thy party wear this rose.
And here I prophesy: this brawl today,
Grown to this faction in the Temple garden,
Shall send, between the red rose and the white,
A thousand souls to death and deadly night.

sp.speaker: PLANTAGENET
sp.l: Good Master Vernon, I am bound to you,
That you on my behalf would pluck a flower.

sp.speaker: VERNON
sp.l: In your behalf still will I wear the same.

sp.speaker: LAWYER
sp.l: And so will I.

sp.speaker: PLANTAGENET
sp.l: Thanks, gentle sir.
Come, let us four to dinner. I dare say
This quarrel will drink blood another day.

div.head: Scene 5
div.stage: Enter Edmund Mortimer, brought in a chair, and Jailers.

sp.speaker: MORTIMER
sp.l: Kind keepers of my weak decaying age,
Let dying Mortimer here rest himself.
Even like a man new-halèd from the rack,
So fare my limbs with long imprisonment;
And these gray locks, the pursuivants of death,
Nestor-like agèd in an age of care,
Argue the end of Edmund Mortimer;
These eyes, like lamps whose wasting oil is spent,
Wax dim, as drawing to their exigent;
Weak shoulders, overborne with burdening grief,
And pithless arms, like to a withered vine
That droops his sapless branches to the ground;
Yet are these feet, whose strengthless stay is numb,
Unable to support this lump of clay,
Swift-wingèd with desire to get a grave,
As witting I no other comfort have.
But tell me, keeper, will my nephew come?

sp.speaker: KEEPER
sp.l: Richard Plantagenet, my lord, will come.
We sent unto the Temple, unto his chamber,
And answer was returned that he will come.

sp.speaker: MORTIMER
sp.l: Enough. My soul shall then be satisfied.
Poor gentleman, his wrong doth equal mine.
Since Henry Monmouth first began to reign,
Before whose glory I was great in arms,
This loathsome sequestration have I had;
And even since then hath Richard been obscured,
Deprived of honor and inheritance.
But now the arbitrator of despairs,
Just Death, kind umpire of men’s miseries,
With sweet enlargement doth dismiss me hence.
I would his troubles likewise were expired,
That so he might recover what was lost.

sp.speaker: KEEPER
sp.l: My lord, your loving nephew now is come.

sp.speaker: MORTIMER
sp.l: Richard Plantagenet, my friend, is he come?

sp.speaker: PLANTAGENET
sp.l: Ay, noble uncle, thus ignobly used,
Your nephew, late despisèd Richard, comes.

sp.speaker: MORTIMER
sp.l: Direct mine arms I may embrace his neck
And in his bosom spend my latter gasp.
O, tell me when my lips do touch his cheeks,
That I may kindly give one fainting kiss.
And now declare, sweet stem from York’s great stock,
Why didst thou say of late thou wert despised?

sp.speaker: PLANTAGENET
sp.l: First, lean thine agèd back against mine arm,
And in that ease I’ll tell thee my disease.
This day, in argument upon a case,
Some words there grew ’twixt Somerset and me,
Among which terms he used his lavish tongue
And did upbraid me with my father’s death;
Which obloquy set bars before my tongue,
Else with the like I had requited him.
Therefore, good uncle, for my father’s sake,
In honor of a true Plantagenet,
And for alliance’ sake, declare the cause
My father, Earl of Cambridge, lost his head.

sp.speaker: MORTIMER
sp.l: That cause, fair nephew, that imprisoned me
And hath detained me all my flow’ring youth
Within a loathsome dungeon, there to pine,
Was cursèd instrument of his decease.

sp.speaker: PLANTAGENET
sp.l: Discover more at large what cause that was,
For I am ignorant and cannot guess.

sp.speaker: MORTIMER
sp.l: I will, if that my fading breath permit
And death approach not ere my tale be done.
Henry the Fourth, grandfather to this king,
Deposed his nephew Richard, Edward’s son,
The first begotten and the lawful heir
Of Edward king, the third of that descent;
During whose reign the Percies of the north,
Finding his usurpation most unjust,
Endeavored my advancement to the throne.
The reason moved these warlike lords to this
Was, for that— young Richard thus removed,
Leaving no heir begotten of his body—
I was the next by birth and parentage;
For by my mother I derivèd am
From Lionel, Duke of Clarence, third son
To King Edward the Third; whereas he
From John of Gaunt doth bring his pedigree,
Being but fourth of that heroic line.
But mark: as in this haughty great attempt
They laborèd to plant the rightful heir,
I lost my liberty and they their lives.
Long after this, when Henry the Fifth,
Succeeding his father Bolingbroke, did reign,
Thy father, Earl of Cambridge then, derived
From famous Edmund Langley, Duke of York,
Marrying my sister that thy mother was,
Again, in pity of my hard distress,
Levied an army, weening to redeem
And have installed me in the diadem.
But, as the rest, so fell that noble earl
And was beheaded. Thus the Mortimers,
In whom the title rested, were suppressed.

sp.speaker: PLANTAGENET
sp.l: Of which, my lord, your Honor is the last.

sp.speaker: MORTIMER
sp.l: True, and thou seest that I no issue have
And that my fainting words do warrant death.
Thou art my heir; the rest I wish thee gather.
But yet be wary in thy studious care.

sp.speaker: PLANTAGENET
sp.l: Thy grave admonishments prevail with me.
But yet methinks my father’s execution
Was nothing less than bloody tyranny.

sp.speaker: MORTIMER
sp.l: With silence, nephew, be thou politic;
Strong-fixèd is the house of Lancaster,
And, like a mountain, not to be removed.
But now thy uncle is removing hence,
As princes do their courts when they are cloyed
With long continuance in a settled place.

sp.speaker: PLANTAGENET
sp.l: O uncle, would some part of my young years
Might but redeem the passage of your age.

sp.speaker: MORTIMER
sp.l: Thou dost then wrong me, as that slaughterer doth
Which giveth many wounds when one will kill.
Mourn not, except thou sorrow for my good;
Only give order for my funeral.
And so farewell, and fair be all thy hopes,
And prosperous be thy life in peace and war.

sp.speaker: PLANTAGENET
sp.l: And peace, no war, befall thy parting soul.
In prison hast thou spent a pilgrimage,
And like a hermit overpassed thy days.—
Well, I will lock his counsel in my breast,
And what I do imagine, let that rest.—
Keepers, convey him hence, and I myself
Will see his burial better than his life.
Here dies the dusky torch of Mortimer,
Choked with ambition of the meaner sort.
And for those wrongs, those bitter injuries,
Which Somerset hath offered to my house,
I doubt not but with honor to redress.
And therefore haste I to the Parliament,
Either to be restorèd to my blood,
Or make mine ill th’ advantage of my good.

div.head: Scene 1

stage.stage: Flourish. Enter King Henry, Exeter, Gloucester, and Winchester; Richard Plantagenet and Warwick, with white roses; Somerset and Suffolk, with red roses; and Others.
Gloucester offers to put up a bill. Winchester snatches it, tears it.

sp.speaker: WINCHESTER
sp.l: Com’st thou with deep premeditated lines,
With written pamphlets studiously devised?
Humphrey of Gloucester, if thou canst accuse
Or aught intend’st to lay unto my charge,
Do it without invention, suddenly,
As I with sudden and extemporal speech
Purpose to answer what thou canst object.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.l: Presumptuous priest, this place commands my patience,
Or thou shouldst find thou hast dishonored me.
Think not, although in writing I preferred
The manner of thy vile outrageous crimes,
That therefore I have forged or am not able
Verbatim to rehearse the method of my pen.
No, prelate, such is thy audacious wickedness,
Thy lewd, pestiferous, and dissentious pranks,
As very infants prattle of thy pride.
Thou art a most pernicious usurer,
Froward by nature, enemy to peace,
Lascivious, wanton, more than well beseems
A man of thy profession and degree.
And for thy treachery, what’s more manifest,
In that thou laid’st a trap to take my life
As well at London Bridge as at the Tower?
Besides, I fear me, if thy thoughts were sifted,
The King, thy sovereign, is not quite exempt
From envious malice of thy swelling heart.

sp.speaker: WINCHESTER
sp.l: Gloucester, I do defy thee.— Lords, vouchsafe
To give me hearing what I shall reply.
If I were covetous, ambitious, or perverse,
As he will have me, how am I so poor?
Or how haps it I seek not to advance
Or raise myself, but keep my wonted calling?
And for dissension, who preferreth peace
More than I do, except I be provoked?
No, my good lords, it is not that offends;
It is not that that hath incensed the Duke.
It is because no one should sway but he,
No one but he should be about the King;
And that engenders thunder in his breast
And makes him roar these accusations forth.
But he shall know I am as good—

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.l: As good!
Thou bastard of my grandfather!

sp.speaker: WINCHESTER
sp.l: Ay, lordly sir; for what are you, I pray,
But one imperious in another’s throne?

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.l: Am I not Protector, saucy priest?

sp.speaker: WINCHESTER
sp.l: And am not I a prelate of the Church?

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.l: Yes, as an outlaw in a castle keeps,
And useth it to patronage his theft.

sp.speaker: WINCHESTER
sp.l: Unreverent Gloucester!

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.l: Thou art reverend
Touching thy spiritual function, not thy life.

sp.speaker: WINCHESTER
sp.l: Rome shall remedy this.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.l: Roam thither then.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: My lord, it were your duty to forbear.

sp.speaker: SOMERSET
sp.l: Ay, so the Bishop be not overborne.
Methinks my lord should be religious,
And know the office that belongs to such.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: Methinks his Lordship should be humbler.
It fitteth not a prelate so to plead.

sp.speaker: SOMERSET
sp.l: Yes, when his holy state is touched so near.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: State holy, or unhallowed, what of that?
Is not his Grace Protector to the King?

sp.speaker: PLANTAGENET
sp.l: Plantagenet, I see, must hold his tongue,
Lest it be said “ Speak, sirrah, when you should;
Must your bold verdict enter talk with lords?”
Else would I have a fling at Winchester.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Uncles of Gloucester and of Winchester,
The special watchmen of our English weal,
I would prevail, if prayers might prevail,
To join your hearts in love and amity.
O, what a scandal is it to our crown
That two such noble peers as you should jar!
Believe me, lords, my tender years can tell
Civil dissension is a viperous worm
That gnaws the bowels of the commonwealth.
sp.stage: A noise within: “ Down with the tawny coats!”
sp.l: What tumult ’s this?

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: An uproar, I dare warrant,
Begun through malice of the Bishop’s men.

sp.speaker: MAYOR
sp.l: O, my good lords, and virtuous Henry,
Pity the city of London, pity us!
The Bishop and the Duke of Gloucester’s men,
Forbidden late to carry any weapon,
Have filled their pockets full of pebble stones
And, banding themselves in contrary parts,
Do pelt so fast at one another’s pate
That many have their giddy brains knocked out;
Our windows are broke down in every street,
And we, for fear, compelled to shut our shops.

div.stage: Enter Servingmen in skirmish with bloody pates.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: We charge you, on allegiance to ourself,
To hold your slaught’ring hands and keep the peace.—
Pray, Uncle Gloucester, mitigate this strife.

sp.speaker: FIRST SERVINGMAN
sp.p:
Nay, if we be forbidden stones, we’ll
fall to it with our teeth.

sp.speaker: SECOND SERVINGMAN
sp.l: Do what you dare, we are as resolute.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.l: You of my household, leave this peevish broil,
And set this unaccustomed fight aside.

sp.speaker: THIRD SERVINGMAN
sp.l: My lord, we know your Grace to be a man
Just and upright, and, for your royal birth,
Inferior to none but to his Majesty;
And ere that we will suffer such a prince,
So kind a father of the commonweal,
To be disgracèd by an inkhorn mate,
We and our wives and children all will fight
And have our bodies slaughtered by thy foes.

sp.speaker: FIRST SERVINGMAN
sp.l: Ay, and the very parings of our nails
Shall pitch a field when we are dead.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.l: Stay, stay, I say!
And if you love me, as you say you do,
Let me persuade you to forbear awhile.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: O, how this discord doth afflict my soul!
Can you, my Lord of Winchester, behold
My sighs and tears, and will not once relent?
Who should be pitiful if you be not?
Or who should study to prefer a peace
If holy churchmen take delight in broils?

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: Yield, my Lord Protector— yield, Winchester—
Except you mean with obstinate repulse
To slay your sovereign and destroy the realm.
You see what mischief, and what murder too,
Hath been enacted through your enmity.
Then be at peace, except you thirst for blood.

sp.speaker: WINCHESTER
sp.l: He shall submit, or I will never yield.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.l: Compassion on the King commands me stoop,
Or I would see his heart out ere the priest
Should ever get that privilege of me.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: Behold, my Lord of Winchester, the Duke
Hath banished moody discontented fury,
As by his smoothèd brows it doth appear.
Why look you still so stern and tragical?

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.l: Here, Winchester, I offer thee my hand.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Fie, Uncle Beaufort! I have heard you preach
That malice was a great and grievous sin;
And will not you maintain the thing you teach,
But prove a chief offender in the same?

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: Sweet king! The Bishop hath a kindly gird.—
For shame, my Lord of Winchester, relent;
What, shall a child instruct you what to do?

sp.speaker: WINCHESTER
sp.l: Well, Duke of Gloucester, I will yield to thee;
Love for thy love and hand for hand I give.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.l: Ay, but I fear me with a hollow heart.—
See here, my friends and loving countrymen,
This token serveth for a flag of truce
Betwixt ourselves and all our followers,
So help me God, as I dissemble not.

sp.speaker: WINCHESTER
sp.l: So help me God, as I intend it not.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: O, loving uncle— kind Duke of Gloucester—
How joyful am I made by this contract.
To the Servingmen. Away, my masters, trouble us no more,
But join in friendship as your lords have done.

sp.speaker: FIRST SERVINGMAN
sp.l: Content. I’ll to the surgeon’s.

sp.speaker: SECOND SERVINGMAN
sp.l: And so will I.

sp.speaker: THIRD SERVINGMAN
sp.p:
And I will see what physic the tavern
affords.

div.stage: They exit with Mayor and Others.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: Accept this scroll, most gracious sovereign,
Which in the right of Richard Plantagenet
We do exhibit to your Majesty.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.l: Well urged, my Lord of Warwick.— For, sweet prince,
An if your Grace mark every circumstance,
You have great reason to do Richard right,
Especially for those occasions
At Eltham Place I told your Majesty.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: And those occasions, uncle, were of force.—
Therefore, my loving lords, our pleasure is
That Richard be restorèd to his blood.

sp.speaker: WARWICK
sp.l: Let Richard be restorèd to his blood;
So shall his father’s wrongs be recompensed.

sp.speaker: WINCHESTER
sp.l: As will the rest, so willeth Winchester.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: If Richard will be true, not that alone
But all the whole inheritance I give
That doth belong unto the house of York,
From whence you spring by lineal descent.

sp.speaker: PLANTAGENET
sp.l: Thy humble servant vows obedience
And humble service till the point of death.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: Stoop then, and set your knee against my foot;
And in reguerdon of that duty done
I girt thee with the valiant sword of York.
Rise, Richard, like a true Plantagenet,
And rise created princely Duke of York.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.l: And so thrive Richard as thy foes may fall!
And as my duty springs, so perish they
That grudge one thought against your Majesty.

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.l: Welcome, high prince, the mighty Duke of York.

sp.speaker: SOMERSET
sp.l: Perish, base prince, ignoble Duke of York.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.l: Now will it best avail your Majesty
To cross the seas and to be crowned in France.
The presence of a king engenders love
Amongst his subjects and his loyal friends,
As it disanimates his enemies.

sp.speaker: KING HENRY
sp.l: When Gloucester says the word, King Henry goes,
For friendly counsel cuts off many foes.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.l: Your ships already are in readiness.

div.stage: Sennet. Flourish. All but Exeter exit.

sp.speaker: EXETER
sp.l: Ay, we may march in England or in France,
Not seeing what is likely to ensue.
This late dissension grown betwixt the peers
Burns under feignèd ashes of forged love
And will at last break out into a flame.
As festered members rot but by degree
Till bones and flesh and sinews fall away,
So will this base and envious discord breed.
And now I fear that fatal prophecy
Which in the time of Henry named the Fifth
Was in the mouth of every sucking babe:
That Henry born at Monmouth should win all,
And Henry born at Windsor should lose all,
Which is so plain that Exeter doth wish
His days may finish ere that hapless time.

div.head: Scene 2
div.stage: Enter Pucelle disguised, with four Soldiers with sacks upon their backs.

sp.speaker: PUCELLE
sp.l: These are the city gates, the gates of Roan,
Through which our policy must make a breach.
Take heed. Be wary how you place your words;
Talk like the vulgar sort of market men
That come to gather money for their corn.
If we have entrance, as I hope we shall,
And that we find the slothful watch but weak,
I’ll by a sign give notice to our friends,
That Charles the Dauphin may encounter them.

sp.speaker: SOLDIER
sp.l: Our sacks shall be a mean to sack the city,
And we be lords and rulers over Roan;
Therefore we’ll knock.

sp.speaker: WATCH
sp.l: Qui là?

sp.speaker: PUCELLE
sp.l: Paysans la pauvre gens de France:
Poor market folks that come to sell their corn.

sp.speaker: WATCH
sp.l: Enter, go in. The market bell is rung.

sp.speaker: PUCELLE
sp.l: Now, Roan, I’ll shake thy bulwarks to the ground.

div.stage: Enter Charles, Bastard, Alanson, Reignier, and Soldiers.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Saint Dennis bless this happy stratagem
And once again we’ll sleep secure in Roan.

sp.speaker: BASTARD
sp.l: Here entered Pucelle and her practisants.
Now she is there, how will she specify
“ Here is the best and safest passage in”?

sp.speaker: REIGNIER
sp.l: By thrusting out a torch from yonder tower,
Which, once discerned, shows that her meaning is:
No way to that, for weakness, which she entered.

div.stage: Enter Pucelle on the top, thrusting out a torch burning.

sp.speaker: PUCELLE
sp.l: Behold, this is the happy wedding torch
That joineth Roan unto her countrymen,
But burning fatal to the Talbonites.

sp.speaker: BASTARD
sp.l: See, noble Charles, the beacon of our friend;
The burning torch, in yonder turret stands.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Now shine it like a comet of revenge,
A prophet to the fall of all our foes!

sp.speaker: REIGNIER
sp.l: Defer no time; delays have dangerous ends.
Enter and cry “ The Dauphin!” presently,
And then do execution on the watch.

div.stage: An Alarum. Enter Talbot in an excursion.

sp.speaker: TALBOT
sp.l: France, thou shalt rue this treason with thy tears,
If Talbot but survive thy treachery.
Pucelle, that witch, that damnèd sorceress,
Hath wrought this hellish mischief unawares,
That hardly we escaped the pride of France.

stage.stage: Bedford brought in sick in a chair, carried by two Attendants. Enter Talbot and Burgundy without; within, Pucelle with a sack of grain, Charles, Bastard, Alanson, and Reignier on the walls.

sp.speaker: PUCELLE
sp.l: Good morrow, gallants. Want you corn for bread?
sp.stage: She scatters grain on those below.
sp.l: I think the Duke of Burgundy will fast
Before he’ll buy again at such a rate.
’Twas full of darnel. Do you like the taste?

sp.speaker: BURGUNDY
sp.l: Scoff on, vile fiend and shameless courtesan!
I trust ere long to choke thee with thine own,
And make thee curse the harvest of that corn.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Your Grace may starve, perhaps, before that time.

sp.speaker: BEDFORD
sp.l: O, let no words, but deeds, revenge this treason.

sp.speaker: PUCELLE
sp.l: What will you do, good graybeard? Break a lance
And run a-tilt at Death within a chair?

sp.speaker: TALBOT
sp.l: Foul fiend of France and hag of all despite,
Encompassed with thy lustful paramours,
Becomes it thee to taunt his valiant age
And twit with cowardice a man half dead?
Damsel, I’ll have a bout with you again,
Or else let Talbot perish with this shame.

sp.speaker: PUCELLE
sp.l: Are you so hot, sir? Yet, Pucelle, hold thy peace,
If Talbot do but thunder, rain will follow.
sp.stage: Those below whisper together in council.
sp.l: God speed the Parliament! Who shall be the Speaker?

sp.speaker: TALBOT
sp.l: Dare you come forth and meet us in the field?

sp.speaker: PUCELLE
sp.l: Belike your Lordship takes us then for fools,
To try if that our own be ours or no.

sp.speaker: TALBOT
sp.l: I speak not to that railing Hecate,
But unto thee, Alanson, and the rest.
Will you, like soldiers, come and fight it out?

sp.speaker: ALANSON
sp.l: Seigneur, no.

sp.speaker: TALBOT
sp.l: Seigneur, hang! Base muleteers of France,
Like peasant footboys do they keep the walls
And dare not take up arms like gentlemen.

sp.speaker: PUCELLE
sp.l: Away, captains. Let’s get us from the walls,
For Talbot means no goodness by his looks.—
Goodbye, my lord. We came but to tell you
That we are here.

sp.speaker: TALBOT
sp.l: And there will we be too, ere it be long,
Or else reproach be Talbot’s greatest fame.—
Vow, Burgundy, by honor of thy house,
Pricked on by public wrongs sustained in France,
Either to get the town again or die.
And I, as sure as English Henry lives,
And as his father here was conqueror,
As sure as in this late-betrayèd town
Great Coeur-de-lion’s heart was burièd,
So sure I swear to get the town or die.

sp.speaker: BURGUNDY
sp.l: My vows are equal partners with thy vows.

sp.speaker: TALBOT
sp.l: But, ere we go, regard this dying prince,
The valiant Duke of Bedford.— Come, my lord,
We will bestow you in some better place,
Fitter for sickness and for crazy age.

sp.speaker: BEDFORD
sp.l: Lord Talbot, do not so dishonor me.
Here will I sit, before the walls of Roan,
And will be partner of your weal or woe.

sp.speaker: BURGUNDY
sp.l: Courageous Bedford, let us now persuade you—

sp.speaker: BEDFORD
sp.l: Not to be gone from hence, for once I read
That stout Pendragon, in his litter sick,
Came to the field and vanquishèd his foes.
Methinks I should revive the soldiers’ hearts
Because I ever found them as myself.

sp.speaker: TALBOT
sp.l: Undaunted spirit in a dying breast,
Then be it so. Heavens keep old Bedford safe!—
And now no more ado, brave Burgundy,
But gather we our forces out of hand
And set upon our boasting enemy.

div.stage: He exits with Burgundy. Bedford and Attendants remain.

stage.stage: Enter Sir John Fastolf and a Captain.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.l: Whither away, Sir John Fastolf, in such haste?

sp.speaker: FASTOLF
sp.l: Whither away? To save myself by flight.
We are like to have the overthrow again.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.l: What, will you fly and leave Lord Talbot?

sp.speaker: FASTOLF
sp.l: Ay,
All the Talbots in the world, to save my life.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.l: Cowardly knight, ill fortune follow thee.

stage.stage: Pucelle, Alanson, and Charles enter, pursued by English Soldiers, and fly.

sp.speaker: BEDFORD
sp.l: Now, quiet soul, depart when heaven please,
For I have seen our enemies’ overthrow.
What is the trust or strength of foolish man?
They that of late were daring with their scoffs
Are glad and fain by flight to save themselves.

stage.stage: and is carried in by two in his chair.

div.stage: An alarum. Enter Talbot, Burgundy, and the rest.

sp.speaker: TALBOT
sp.l: Lost and recovered in a day again!
This is a double honor, Burgundy.
Yet heavens have glory for this victory.

sp.speaker: BURGUNDY
sp.l: Warlike and martial Talbot, Burgundy
Enshrines thee in his heart, and there erects
Thy noble deeds as valor’s monuments.

sp.speaker: TALBOT
sp.l: Thanks, gentle duke. But where is Pucelle now?
I think her old familiar is asleep.
Now where’s the Bastard’s braves and Charles his gleeks?
What, all amort? Roan hangs her head for grief
That such a valiant company are fled.
Now will we take some order in the town,
Placing therein some expert officers,
And then depart to Paris to the King,
For there young Henry with his nobles lie.

sp.speaker: BURGUNDY
sp.l: What wills Lord Talbot pleaseth Burgundy.

sp.speaker: TALBOT
sp.l: But yet, before we go, let’s not forget
The noble Duke of Bedford late-deceased,
But see his exequies fulfilled in Roan.
A braver soldier never couchèd lance,
A gentler heart did never sway in court.
But kings and mightiest potentates must die,
For that’s the end of human misery.

div.head: Scene 3
div.stage: Enter Charles, Bastard, Alanson, Pucelle, and Soldiers.

sp.speaker: PUCELLE
sp.l: Dismay not, princes, at this accident,
Nor grieve that Roan is so recoverèd.
Care is no cure, but rather corrosive
For things that are not to be remedied.
Let frantic Talbot triumph for a while,
And like a peacock sweep along his tail;
We’ll pull his plumes and take away his train,
If dauphin and the rest will be but ruled.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: We have been guided by thee hitherto,
And of thy cunning had no diffidence.
One sudden foil shall never breed distrust.

sp.speaker: BASTARD
sp.l: Search out thy wit for secret policies,
And we will make thee famous through the world.

sp.speaker: ALANSON
sp.l: We’ll set thy statue in some holy place
And have thee reverenced like a blessèd saint.
Employ thee then, sweet virgin, for our good.

sp.speaker: PUCELLE
sp.l: Then thus it must be; this doth Joan devise:
By fair persuasions mixed with sugared words
We will entice the Duke of Burgundy
To leave the Talbot and to follow us.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Ay, marry, sweeting, if we could do that,
France were no place for Henry’s warriors,
Nor should that nation boast it so with us,
But be extirpèd from our provinces.

sp.speaker: ALANSON
sp.l: Forever should they be expulsed from France,
And not have title of an earldom here.

sp.speaker: PUCELLE
sp.l: Your honors shall perceive how I will work
To bring this matter to the wishèd end.
Hark! By the sound of drum you may perceive
Their powers are marching unto Paris-ward.
There goes the Talbot with his colors spread,
And all the troops of English after him.
Now in the rearward comes the Duke and his.
Fortune in favor makes him lag behind.
Summon a parley; we will talk with him.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: A parley with the Duke of Burgundy!

sp.speaker: BURGUNDY
sp.l: Who craves a parley with the Burgundy?

sp.speaker: PUCELLE
sp.l: The princely Charles of France, thy countryman.

sp.speaker: BURGUNDY
sp.l: What say’st thou, Charles?— for I am marching hence.

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.l: Speak, Pucelle, and enchant him with thy words.

sp.speaker: PUCELLE
sp.l: Brave Burgundy, undoubted hope of France,
Stay; let thy humble handmaid speak to thee.

sp.speaker: BURGUNDY
sp.l: Speak on, but be not over-tedious.

sp.speaker: PUCELLE
sp.l: Look on thy country, look on fertile France,
And see the cities and the towns defaced
By wasting ruin of the cruel foe.
As looks the mother on her lowly babe
When death doth close his tender-dying eyes,
See, see the pining malady of France:
Behold the wounds, the most unnatural wounds,
Which thou thyself hast given her woeful breast.
O, turn thy edgèd sword another way;
Strike those that hurt, and hurt not those that help.
One drop of blood drawn from thy country’s bosom
Should grieve thee more than streams of foreign gore.
Return thee therefore with a flood of tears,
And wash away thy country’s stainèd spots.

sp.speaker: BURGUNDY
